in half the last time
the US government decided
it wanted to build a wall.

And Ray and D'Ann Loop
couldn't believe it.

Their family had been
farming this south Texas land

for nearly 100 years
until the notice came
the government was taking it.
D'ANN LOOP: I was very angry.

And I just kept saying over
and over again, how can
they do that.

How is that possible
in the United States
that they can do this?

Put up a fence in front of our
land and then keep us in here,
you know, lock us in?
I didn't understand.
I was very--
I was floored and flabbergasted.

DREW GRIFFIN: That was
almost 10 years ago.

And the Loops, like hundreds
of other landowners,
thought they could fight.
They lost.

The government paid
them a settlement

and took the land it
needed to build this fence,
cutting their farm in two.

RAY LOOP: It essentially
left us no property

on the US side of
the border wall,

including my house,
my residence.

Everything was behind
on the Mexican side
of the US border fence.

DREW GRIFFIN: Unbelievably,
these American citizens

were locked out of
their own country.

Their farm ended up on the
south side of the border fence,

still on US soil but
wedged between the fence
and the border with Mexico.

Their only access to the rest
of the US, a locked gate.

RAY LOOP: There's not
really words to describe it.
We've learned to live with it.

But when you come and you
enter the border gate,

you will punch your
code in and you

come behind the
border wall, there
is a feeling of isolation.

DREW GRIFFIN: A few months
ago, the family found out just
how isolated they really are.

In the middle of the
night, a fire broke out.

And as the fire
raged, fire engines

were slow to get there,
hampered by that border fence.

D'ANN LOOP: And I kept
standing there yelling,
where are they, Ray?
I had called 911.
She was clear.
She heard me on the call.
She knew where I was.

But they couldn't get in here,
according to our neighbors.

They said the fire trucks kept
driving up and down the street.
We heard the fire trucks.

DREW GRIFFIN: The
family got out, barely.
But not their pets.

D'ANN LOOP: We had a
little miniature goat.
He was on fire.

And he was running
out of the structure

screaming because he
was burning alive.
Everything was gone.

We couldn't-- he told me you
cannot go back in for them.

And we all stood in the
yard, and we had to listen
to their cries, burning alive.

And we couldn't go
back in and save them.

DREW GRIFFIN: The Loops' story
is part of a CNN analysis

of 442 lawsuits filed
by the US government
against American landowners.

The property owners either
fought to keep their land

or tried to get more money
than the federal government was
offering under eminent domain.

In most cases, a CNN analysis
found those landowners
lost the battle.

And a decade later, 93 of the
lawsuits are still in court.

What did all those
landowners get?

A total of $78 million,
the fair market

value to cover 654 miles of
current border fence land
the government took.

But what happened 10 years
ago in mostly desolate,

dry ranch land will
be nothing compared
to what's about to take place.

President Trump's
recent executive order

to expand the border wall
could stretch into more
highly populated areas.

It will bisect even
more farms, golf

courses, resorts and ranches,
hundreds of miles of wall.

And hundreds, if not
thousands of landowners,

will be forced to sell their
property to the government.

Former Customs and
Border Protection

Commissioner Ralph
Basham says expect
huge, prolonged, legal battles.

RALPH BASHAM: Particularly
in the urban areas,

it's going to be
very complicated.
It's going to be--
it's not a popular idea.

And like I said, individuals
are not happy when they
lose part of their property.

DREW GRIFFIN: The
River Bend Golf

Club and Resort in Brownsville,
Texas is bracing for the worst.

The fence is already here
on the right and the left.

If the government
decides to finish it,
it will cut the resort in two.

JEREMY BARNARD:
70% of our property

would be on the south
side of the wall.

That would affect 15 of our
18 holes of the golf course
and over 200 residences.

DREW GRIFFIN: Jeremy Barnard
is the general manager

and says residents here
will fight for fair value
of their property.

JEREMY BARNARD: I don't think
anybody here is just going
to hand over their property.

DREW GRIFFIN: Pat
Bell is one of them.

PAT BELL: --what happens
here means everything to me.

DREW GRIFFIN: Like
almost everyone

CNN talked to along this border,
Bell is a Trump supporter.

But she does not support
a wall, especially one

that would essentially move her
home to the Mexican side of it.

She says fences and
walls don't work,

which is exactly why she plans
to fight for her property.

PAT BELL: So absolutely
I would go to the people
that are in charge.

And you hate to say
I would get a lawyer,

but if it come to that issue
and you had to, you would.

DREW GRIFFIN: Bell, like
thousands of other property

owners along this
border, nervously wait

the final design, placement
and eventual legal notice

that the US government is
coming to take away their land.

ANDERSON COOPER:
Drew joins us now.

So to be clear, Drew,
no notices have gone
out yet to property owners.

But if the President does
go ahead with the wall,
how would things then unfold?

DREW GRIFFIN: Anderson,
if history repeats itself,

landowners will be forced
to sell their property

to the government,
lose their land,

and not be paid what they
think that land is worth.

We have done an
extensive analysis

of all the lawsuits that
came out of the 2006
border fence expansion.

And what we found,
Anderson, is that property

owners who fought the government
to keep their land always lost.

And the government offered
them thousands of dollars

less than what the
land was worth.

That's from within 400 lawsuits
that people lost their land,

lost their court
battles, and got paid
less than what they wanted.
